div.a: Learning Resources and Other Family Resources During School Closure ...

header.h1: Learning Resources and Other Family Resources During School Closure

article.span: Breaking News / Community / Employees / Parents / Students

img.alt: Collage of 3 photos: Student at home computer, health center hallway and sack lunches

h3.strong: Family Resources During the Coronavirus Shutdown
Schools Closed for Remainder of School Year

section.p: On April 8, Oregon Gov. Kate Brown announced that all schools will remain closed for the rest of the school year, through June 15. Read our letter to families here.
Below are some answers to frequent questions we are getting. This document will be updated often, so please keep checking back.

We will continue to provide breakfast and lunch pickups next week from 9-11 a.m. at David Douglas High School South Building, Ron Russell Middle School, Ventura Park Elementary and Gilbert Heights Elementary.
You can see family resource information about food, supplemental education, daycare, health care at the links above.

h5.strong: Q: What can I do to reduce the risk of getting COVID-19?

section.p: A: You can help yourself, and your students reduce their risk for getting and spreading viral respiratory infections, including the flu and the common cold, by encouraging them to take simple steps which will also help prevent COVID-19:

ul.li: Wash your hands often with warm water and soap.
Cover your mouth with a tissue, sleeve, or elbow (not hands) when you cough or sneeze, and then wash your hands.
Stay home if you’re sick. Employees who are well but who have a sick family member at home with COVID-19 should notify their supervisor.
Keep your immune system strong by eating a healthy diet, getting enough sleep, regular exercise, and by taking care of underlying health conditions.
Clean your personal work station, keyboard, phones, and other high touch areas.
There are also basic steps every household should take to prepare for any unexpected event:

Make sure you have a good supply of foods, drinks, medications, pet supplies, and other necessities you would want if you needed to stay home and limit your contact with other people for a couple weeks.
Get to know your neighbors, especially those who might need extra help like seniors or people living alone.
In the face of rumors, check multco.us/covid19 for reliable information.

h5.strong: Q: Will there be scheduled “make up” days for the 2019-2020 school year as a result of this emergency closure?

section.p: A: Right now, DDSD is unsure of the closure’s implications on the remaining school calendars; we will share more about this as we get guidance from the Oregon Department of Education.

h5.strong: Q: What does the extended closure mean for graduation dates for 2020?

section.p: A: At this time, DDSD does not know the exact implications of this extended closure on seniors slated for graduation this spring. The Oregon Department of Education is actively working on this matter, and additional details will be forthcoming. It is important to remember that all schools in the state and many across the country are in the same situation.

h5.strong: Q: What are David Douglas’s plans for providing instruction to students during the closure?

section.p: A: We understand there is a need for students to continue to Grow, Learn and Thrive during this extended closure. We have placed some options for supplemental learning activities at the Learning Resources link above, and we are working on plans to get even more robust offerings to you in the coming days and weeks. But it is also important to know that these options do not replace state-mandated instructional hours.

h5.strong: Q: What does the closure mean for athletic practices, games, and other extra-curricular activities?

section.p: A: All athletic and extra-curricular activities are canceled through June 15. This includes all meetings, practices, plays, concerts, competitions, etc. Spring athletics are canceled through June 15; more information about this matter is forthcoming from the Oregon School Activities Association.

h5.strong: Q: What is happening to funds paid by families for school trips that were initially scheduled during the closure?

section.p: A: We are aware this question is of great importance, particularly as many families feel their cash flow negatively impacted. Staff is reviewing planned trips by school and will be working to issue refunds for trips that won’t occur. This process may take a couple weeks dependent upon any further closure notifications.

h5.strong: Q: Is there food available for my students and family?

section.p: A: During the closure DDSD is serving breakfast and lunch at four DDSD sites. From 9:00 – 11:00 a.m. (Mon-Fri) families can pick up both sack breakfast and lunches to go. They will be available during spring break.

ul.li: David Douglas High School
Gilbert Heights Elementary
Ron Russell Middle School
Ventura Park Elementary School

section.p: In addition, Food Pantries are open to everyone in the community on the following days and times, and at the following locations:

ul.li: David Douglas High School South Building: 5-6:30 p.m. Thursdays.
Cherry Park Elementary: 3:45-5:30 p.m. Mondays, and 9:30-10:30 a.m. Wednesdays.
Gilbert Park Elementary: 2-4 p.m. Wednesdays
Mill Park Elementary: 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Tuesdays.

h5.strong: Q: What if my family does not have access to the Internet or a computer device for my student to use?

section.p: A: David Douglas School District will provide families with a (1) Chromebook if they do not have a home computer/laptop/tablet. We plan to distribute these during the week of April 6. The current plan is to distribute Chromebooks to families at our 4 Grab-and-Go food sites. We created a Family Chromebook Request Google form for you to fill out if you need a Chromebook:

h5.strong: Q: Is the Student Based Health Center still open?

section.p: A: During the closure, Multnomah County will keep only the Parkrose Student Based Health Center open. Beginning on March 23, it will continue to offer in-person visits for certain conditions when necessary after the concern is evaluated over the phone. Telemedicine appointments will also be available.
Please call 503-988-3392 for more information about appointments at Parkrose Student Health Center.

Student Health Centers are open to all Multnomah County students ages 5-18. Please call prior to coming into a center so that they are able to assist you as best they can. You will need to call and make an appointment.

p.a: View an archive of our Covid-19 communications here

a.title:
Welcome to the David Douglas School Board Notes page. Each month, our School Board meets to discuss specific agenda items, deliberate proposed action items and hear the concerns and questions of District residents.
You can watch our Board meetings live and the official minutes are adopted and published on our website a month following each meeting. But often there is deeper context to issues that doesn’t come out during meetings, or there are answers to questions from District residents that don’t always get shared with the general public.
That’s what this page is for. Each month following our Board meetings, we will update this page to provide some of the highlights of each meeting and answer some of the questions.
To view our Board Meetings click here
